channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Lyle Goldstein on China and the Vietnamese Military
item.description: With friction rising in the South China Sea, Professor Goldstein, of the China Maritime Studies Institute at the Naval War College in Rhode Island, discusses the current state of Vietnam’s military and Chinese perceptions of it.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: A Vietnamese coast guard vessel, right, followed a Chinese coast guard ship in disputed waters in the South China Sea in May.

item.title: Militant Leader in Rare Appearance in Iraq
item.description: The leader of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, took the all but unprecedented step of delivering a videotaped sermon at a mosque in Mosul.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Al-Furqan Media, via Agence France-Presse -- Getty Images
item.media:description: An image of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the head of ISIS, taken from a video of a sermon he gave Friday in Mosul, Iraq.

item.title: Autopsy Suggests Palestinian Teenager Was Burned to Death After Abduction
item.description: An examination of the teenager who was snatched from an East Jerusalem street and slain this week found soot in his lungs, according to a senior Palestinian official briefed on the early results.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muhammad Hussein Abu Khdeir's father, center, greeted men who paid their condolences on Saturday.

item.title: News Analysis: Power Struggles in Middle East Exploit Islam’s Ancient Sectarian Rift
item.description: Bahrain, the first place where Arab Spring protests degenerated into Sunni-Shiite feuds, now appears to have been a signal of what was to come in the Middle East.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A Bahraini protester during clashes with police in Sanabis, west of Manama, on Thursday. Bahrain’s Sunni allies have helped quell the Shiite-dominated uprising.

item.title: Open Source: Beating of Palestinian-American Boy Caught on Video
item.description: A video posted online appears to show Israeli police officers beating a Palestinian-American boy after his detention on Thursday during protests in East Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:credit: Courtesy of the Abu Khdeir family
item.media:description: The battered face of Tariq Khdeir, 15, a Palestinian-American arrested on Thursday in East Jerusalem by the Israeli police.

item.title: Militant Leader in Rare Appearance in Iraq
item.description: The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria released a video of a sermon delivered by its leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, at a mosque in Mosul, Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: An image of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the head of ISIS, taken from a video of a sermon he gave Friday in Mosul, Iraq.

item.title: Shadow of Brutal ’79 War Darkens Vietnam’s View of China Relations
item.description: Memories of a short but ferocious conflict between Vietnam and China in 1979 permeate the current sour relations between the two Communist countries now at odds over contested waters in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Justin Mott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ha Thi Hien along a rail line in Lang Son connecting Hanoi and Beijing.

item.title: Pro-Russian Fighters Routed From Stronghold, Ukraine Says
item.description: The Ukrainian government said Saturday that it had pushed pro-Russian fighters out of Slovyansk, a long-blockaded rebel stronghold where some of the fiercest fighting has occurred during the more than three-month separatist insurrection.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Pro-Russian fighters boarded a bus on Saturday as they left their positions in eastern Ukraine. The government in Kiev appeared to have won a major victory.

item.title: World Cup 2014: In an Amazon Village Built for Buoyancy, the Game of Soccer Plays On
item.description: A inhabitants of a floating village in the Amazon River Basin have adapted their lives, and their passion for playing soccer, to the annual flooding of the Black River.
item.dc:creator: By JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy carries a goal for playing soocer with friends on the dock of a restaurant in Catalão, Brazil.

item.title: After Barrage of Personal Attacks, Indonesian Presidential Election Tightens
item.description: As voters prepare for Wednesday’s election, the race between a populist governor and a former army general is considered too close to call.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Joko Widodo, in Bandung on Thursday, has seen his double-digit lead shrink in a poll.

item.title: Amid Modi’s Centrist Shift, an Aide With a Turbulent Past Rises
item.description: After two Hindu men were killed in an altercation with Muslims last summer, Sanjeev Balyan rallied crowds from his caste, and a week later 60 people were dead.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:credit: Government Information Dept/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi flagging a train run in Kashmir.

item.title: Opinion: Are Neocons Getting Ready to Ally With Hillary Clinton?
item.description: The neoconservative movement may be connecting with Hillary Clinton in a bid to to return to the driver’s seat of American foreign policy.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JACOB HEILBRUNN
item.media:credit: Left, Stephanie Sinclair/VII via Corbis; right, Colin McPherson/Corbis
item.media:description: Neocons like the historian Robert Kagan may be connecting with Hillary Clinton to try to regain influence in foreign policy.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Dhaka’s Poisoned Fruit
item.description: In Bangladesh, tainted food brings attention to the chasm between country and city.
item.dc:creator: By TAHMIMA ANAM

item.title: Prototype: Shaping a School System, From the Ground Up
item.description: In starting a new educational network in Peru, a businessman turned to Ideo, a design company, to help devise everything from classrooms to business models.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE MARTIN
item.media:credit: Thor Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Ideo’s offices in San Francisco, from left, Sally Madsen, Sandy Speicher and Kate Lydon work on plans for Innova Schools, the educational network they are designing for a Peruvian businessman.

item.title: Opinion: North Korea’s Fear of Hollywood
item.description: Why does a dictator with nukes freak out about a James Franco sendup? Because he’s so into movies. Really.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL FISCHER

item.title: Georgian Opposition Leader Ordered Jailed Until Trial
item.description: Gigi Ugulava is among more than 10 senior United National Movement officials who have been arrested on various charges, in what critics say is a wave of politically motivated prosecutions.
item.dc:creator: By OLESYA VARTANYAN

item.title: Egypt Sharply Raises Prices for Fuel, Drawing Protests
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi signals he will forge ahead with a series of austerity measures despite official concerns about a public backlash.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: 4 Killed in Attack Near Somali Parliament
item.description: The targeting of members of Parliament appears to be a new strategy for Shabab militants, who have previously attacked United Nations staff members, government officials and African Union peacekeepers.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A car exploded at a checkpoint in Mogadishu, killing soldiers and refugees at a nearby camp.

item.title: On Soccer: For Bellicose Brazil, Payback Carries Heavy Price: Loss of Neymar
item.description: The referee’s failure to control Friday’s game contributed to an ugly atmosphere and a World Cup-ending injury to Brazil’s star striker.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN

item.title: Ukraine Claims Victory in Rebel Stronghold
item.description: Ukraine's forces claimed a significant success against pro-Russian insurgents on Saturday, chasing them from one of their strongholds in the embattled east of the country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces at a checkpoint near Slovyansk on Saturday.

item.title: Fair Game: When Taxes and Profits Are Oceans Apart
item.description: Many American companies won’t divulge the tax bills they would face by bringing home their overseas earnings. It’s a figure that investors could benefit from knowing.
item.dc:creator: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

item.title: An Online Shift in China Muffles an Open Forum
item.description: A turn from the microblogging service Sina Weibo to the Facebook-like WeChat has reoriented the nation’s social media landscape from public to semiprivate communication.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: In recent months, Weibo has been eclipsed by WeChat, which allows instant messaging within self-selected circles of followers.

item.title: Emilio Álvarez Montalván, Nicaragua’s Pro-Democracy Sage, Dies at 94
item.description: Dr. Álvarez was an ophthalmologist, former guerrilla, political prisoner, diplomat and trenchant critic of dictatorship, was often called the wisest man in Nicaragua.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN KINZER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Make More Arrests in Huge Hong Kong Protest
item.description: Protest leaders say the police are trying to stifle dissent by carrying out arrests as pro-democracy groups plan more demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Chinese Leader, Underlining Ties to South Korea, Cites Japan as Onetime Mutual Enemy
item.description: President Xi Jinping reminded South Koreans on Friday that their two countries had fought “shoulder to shoulder” against Japan more than four centuries ago.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China speaking in Seoul, South Korea, on Friday.
